DataElement.preferredName: Invasive Breast Malignant Neoplasm Microcalcification Ind-3
DataElement.preferredDefinition: a yes/no indicator to ask if tiny deposits of calcium in breast tissue are present indicating cancer with accompanying spread of malignant atypical neoplastic cell growth into healthy tissue.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to tiny deposits of calcium in breast tissue which indicate presence of cancer with accompanying spread of malignant atypical neoplastic cell growth into healthy tissue.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: marked by a tendency to spread especially into healthy tissue.:One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.
One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: marked by a tendency to spread especially into healthy tissue.:(MY-krow-kal-si-fi-KAY-shunz) Tiny deposits of calcium in the breast that cannot be felt but can be detected on a mammogram. A cluster of these very small specks of calcium may indicate that cancer is present.

Concepts.definition: Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.
Tiny deposits of calcium in tissue.  In the breast they can be seen using mammography, and if found in clusters may be indicative of breast cancer.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: updated for ISO compliance and to provide naming consistency for related elements

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual domain that includes value meanings to be used for Indicator Value Meanings such as Yes, No, Unknown, No Applicable

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A caDSR representation term that is used to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no/unknown.

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of yes, no, or unknown.
